66,52,"a. Ministry of Company Affairs (MCA) maintains the details of all the Directors of  all the companies with a unique Identification Number which is called Director Identification Number (DIN).  b. Every director needs to have a DIN form MCA.  DIN form is available on the  website of MCA.  Before formation of the PC all the Directors / Chairman should have DIN.  c. If any Director got a DIN, the same need not be obtained afresh. d. MCA on online application provides DIN at a cost of Rs. 1000/- against identity  proof.  For identity only PAN Card, Voter ID Card, Passport or Driving License number is accepted.   3.9 How the company is named?  a. Every Producer Company name should be unique. b. Every Producer Company name should end with ""Producer Company Limited"" which  indicates its status as Producer Company.  c. The Producer Company may be named in such a way that it inspires the entire  membership and creates a sense of ownership for its members and is to be indicative of the objectives of the company.  d.","Farmer Producer Organisations Frequently Asked Questions (Faqs),3.8 What Is Director Identification Number (Din)?",,,,,176,input/md/english/FARMER PRODUCER ORGANISATIONS.pdf,para,,"The Ministry of Company Affairs maintains the details of all company Directors with a unique Director Identification Number (DIN), which is required for all directors and is available on the MCA website. Before forming a Producer Company, all Directors/Chairmen should have a DIN, and once obtained, it does not need to be obtained afresh. The MCA provides DIN through online application at a cost of Rs. 1000, accepting only PAN Card, Voter ID Card, Passport, or Driving License number for identity proof. Every Producer Company name should be unique and end with ""Producer Company Limited,"" indicating its status, and it should inspire membership and reflect the company's objectives."

67,52,"It is a better idea not to use the name of the Producer Organization Promoting Institution  (POPI) directly or indirectly in the Producer Company name.  Using POPI name will not help in creating ownership in the minds of the members.  e. Apply for the name online to MCA in e-form INC-1. f. A fee of Rs. 1000/- is to be paid along with e-from INC-1. g. Digital Signature of the applicant for the name is to be attached. h. If the name is not available, RoC will inform about the same.  This necessitates submission  of fresh set of names in the same application.","Farmer Producer Organisations Frequently Asked Questions (Faqs),3.8 What Is Director Identification Number (Din)?",,,,,103,input/md/english/FARMER PRODUCER ORGANISATIONS.pdf,para,,"The Director Identification Number (DIN) is a unique identification number for individuals serving as directors of a company. It is recommended not to use the name of the Producer Organization Promoting Institution (POPI) in the Producer Company name to avoid creating ownership confusion. To apply for the name online, the e-form INC-1 should be submitted to the Ministry of Corporate Affairs (MCA), along with a fee of Rs. 1000 and the digital signature of the applicant. If the desired name is not available, the Registrar of Companies (RoC) will provide this information, requiring the submission of a fresh set of names in the same application."

68,72,"a. MoA is a document that indicates what activities the company can undertake. b. MoA needs to be prepared carefully to cover all the activities planned for the present and  future of the Producer Company in a broad manner.  c. MoA should be prepared and printed on both sides of the paper. d. It is to be subscribed/signed by the requisite number of subscribers/promoters in his/her  own hand along with details like father's name, occupation, address and the number of shares subscribed for, by them.  e. MoA needs to be dated after the date of stamping of the Articles of Association (AoA).","Farmer Producer Organisations Frequently Asked Questions (Faqs),3.10 What Is Memorandum Of Association (Moa)?",,,,,102,input/md/english/FARMER PRODUCER ORGANISATIONS.pdf,para,,"The Memorandum of Association (MoA) outlines the activities a company can undertake and should cover present and future plans broadly. It must be carefully prepared and printed on both sides of the paper, and signed by the required number of subscribers with specific details. The MoA should be dated after the stamping of the Articles of Association (AoA) and is crucial for outlining the scope of a Producer Company's operations."

69,73,"a. AoA is a document that specifies the rules for a company's operations.   b. It defines the company's purpose and lays out how tasks are to be accomplished within  the organization.  c. It includes the process for appointing Directors and how financial records are handled. d. AoA should be prepared and printed on both sides of the paper. e. It is to be subscribed/signed by the requisite number of subscribers/promoters in his/her  own hand along with details like father's name, occupation, address and the number of shares subscribed for.","Farmer Producer Organisations Frequently Asked Questions (Faqs),3.11 What Is Articles Of Association (Aoa)?",,,,,89,input/md/english/FARMER PRODUCER ORGANISATIONS.pdf,para,,"The Articles of Association (AoA) is a document that outlines the rules for a company's operations, including its purpose and how tasks are to be carried out. It also covers the process for appointing Directors and the handling of financial records. The AoA should be prepared and printed on both sides of the paper, and subscribed/signed by the required number of subscribers/promoters along with specific details."

70,74,"incorporation of a Producer Company?  a. Copy of the letter of RoC confirming the availability of name. b. MoA and AoA duly stamped and signed. c. Form INC-22 indicating the Registered Office of the company with full address. d. Form DIR-12 in duplicate with details about the directors of the company. e. Form INC-7 on stamp paper declaring compliance with all and incidental matters  regarding formation of companies.  f. Consent of each of the Directors along with form DIR-12. g.  An affidavit indicating that MoA is fully understood by the subscribers/signees, if they  sign in Hindi.  h. Power of Attorney to the agent who is dealing with the RoC to make corrections in MoA  and AoA, if necessary, to the satisfaction of the RoC.","Farmer Producer Organisations Frequently Asked Questions (Faqs),3.12 What Are The Documents To Be Submitted To The Registrar Of Companies (Roc) For",,,,,124,input/md/english/FARMER PRODUCER ORGANISATIONS.pdf,para,,"The documents required for the incorporation of a Producer Company include a confirmation of name availability from the Registrar of Companies, duly stamped and signed MoA and AoA, Form INC-22 indicating the Registered Office, and Form DIR-12 with details about the directors. Additionally, Form INC-7 on stamp paper declaring compliance, consent of each director with form DIR-12, and an affidavit for signees understanding MoA in Hindi are needed. 71,75,"a. CoC is issued by the RoC as a conclusive proof of formation of a Producer Company. b. Producer Company is effective and comes into existence from the date mentioned in the  Certificate of Registration granted by the RoC.a. On incorporation and from the date mentioned in the Certificate of Commencement  (CoC), the company becomes a person in the eyes of law.  b. It has perpetual succession, meaning members may come and go, but it will go on until it  is wound up by following the process of law.  c.  It has a common seal, which is affixed on all the documents executed on behalf of the  company in the presence of a director and signed by the authorized signatory or signatories.  d. It is empowered to hold the properties in its own name and has its own right. e. It can enter into contracts in its own name. f. It can sue others and can be sued by others. g. In simple terms it has contractual capacity in the eyes of law just like any other person  who has contractual capacity.","3.14 What Is The Legal Status Of A Producer Company?,Farmer Producer Organisations Frequently Asked Questions (Faqs),3.13 What Is Certificate Of Commencement (Coc)?",,,,,183,input/md/english/FARMER PRODUCER ORGANISATIONS.pdf,para,,"The Certificate of Commencement (CoC) is issued by the RoC as conclusive proof of the formation of a Producer Company, and it comes into existence from the date mentioned in the Certificate of Registration. Upon incorporation and from the date mentioned in the CoC, the company becomes a legal entity with perpetual succession, a common seal, and the ability to hold properties, enter contracts, and engage in legal proceedings. Essentially, it has the same contractual capacity as any other legal entity."

72,77,"a. It is estimated that it may cost Rs. 40,000/- approximately. b. It depends on the fee charged by CA, Company Secretary and Authorized Agents etc.a. Initially the promoters of the company will bear the cost of registration of the  company.  b. The promoters are generally the Producer Organisation Promoting Institution (POPI)  or the initial directors.  3.18  Whether Producer Company reimburses the cost of registration to the promoters?  The cost of registration may be reimbursed to the promoters duly approved by its general body in its first meeting with a resolution passed to that effect.  3.19  Who will run a Producer Company? The company is run / governed by members/shareholders, Board of Directors and Office bearers.","Farmer Producer Organisations Frequently Asked Questions (Faqs),3.16 How Much It Costs For Registration Of A Producer Company?,3.17 Who Will Bear The Cost Of The Registration Of A Producer Company?",,,,,117,input/md/english/FARMER PRODUCER ORGANISATIONS.pdf,para,,"The registration of a producer company may cost approximately Rs. 40,000 and depends on the fees charged by professionals. Initially, the promoters of the company bear the registration costs, and these promoters are typically the Producer Organisation Promoting Institution (POPI) or the initial directors. The cost of registration may be reimbursed to the promoters with approval from the general body in the company's first meeting. The producer company is run and governed by its members/shareholders, Board of Directors, and office bearers."

73,79,"a. Board of Directors are elected by the members. b. BoD may act collectively only through meetings.c. An office bearer is a person who is selected / appointed to look after the dayto-day affairs of the Producer Company.  d. The office bearers include Chief Executive officer (CEO), Accountant, godown  keeper, etc.    e. The company pays salaries to all the office bearers.","Farmer Producer Organisations Frequently Asked Questions (Faqs),3.20 Who Are Board Of Directors (Bod)?,3.21 Who Are Office Bearers?",,,,,62,input/md/english/FARMER PRODUCER ORGANISATIONS.pdf,para,,"The Board of Directors are elected by the members and may act collectively only through meetings. An office bearer is a person selected or appointed to look after the day-to-day affairs of the Producer Company, including roles such as Chief Executive Officer, Accountant, and godown keeper. The company pays salaries to all the office bearers."

74,81,a. By subscribing to the MoA. b. By an agreement in writing to become a member and with an entry in the  register.a. Approve Budget and adopt Annual Accounts of the Company b. Approve the quantum of withheld price c. Approve the patronage bonus d. Authorize the issue of bonus shares e. Appoint an auditor f. Declare a dividend and decide on the distribution of patronage g. Amend the MoA and AoA h. Specify the conditions and limits of loans that may be given by the Board to  any Director  i. Approve any act or any other matter that is specifically reserved in the  articles for decision for members,"Farmer Producer Organisations Frequently Asked Questions (Faqs),3.22 How To Become A Member Of A Producer Company?,3.23 What Is The Authority Of The Members On The Company? Members Exert Authority On The Company Only Through General Meetings. The General Meetings Alone Can Do The Following:",,,,,110,input/md/english/FARMER PRODUCER ORGANISATIONS.pdf,para,,"Members exert authority on the company only through general meetings, which can approve various actions such as budget adoption, withholding price quantum, and appointing auditors. They also have the power to declare dividends, amend the MoA and AoA, and approve specific matters reserved for members' decision. Membership can be obtained by subscribing to the MoA or through a written agreement and entry in the register. Additionally, members can authorize the issue of bonus shares, decide on the distribution of patronage, and specify conditions and limits of loans given by the board to any director."

75,83,"a. to transfer one's shares b. to vote on resolutions at meetings of the Company c. to requisition an extraordinary general meeting of the Company or to make a  joint requisitions  d. to receive notice of a general meeting; to attend and speak in a general  meeting  e. to move amendments to resolutions proposed at meetings f. in case the member is a corporate body, to appoint a representative to  attend and vote at general meetings on its behalf  g. to require the company to circulate its resolutions  h. to enjoy the profits of the company in the form of dividends i. to elect directors and to participate in the management of the company  through them  j. to apply to the Company Law Board in case of oppression  k. to apply to the Company Law Board in case of mismanagement l. to apply to the court for winding up of the company m. to share the surplus on winding up n. to have a share certificate issued to him/her in respect of his/her shares","Farmer Producer Organisations Frequently Asked Questions (Faqs),3.24 What Are The Rights Of The Members?",,,,,174,input/md/english/FARMER PRODUCER ORGANISATIONS.pdf,para,,"Members of Farmer Producer Organisations have rights including transferring shares, voting on resolutions, requisitioning meetings, receiving notice of meetings, moving amendments to resolutions, appointing representatives for corporate bodies, enjoying profits in the form of dividends, electing directors, participating in management, applying for relief in case of oppression or mismanagement, applying for winding up of the company, sharing surplus on winding up, and having a share certificate issued."

76,84,"a. In case of Producer Company comprising only of individual members or combination  of individual members and producer institutions, then the voting rights shall be based on one vote per member.  b. In case of Producer Company consisting only of producer institutions, then the voting  rights shall be based on the participation in the business of the Producer Company in the previous year.  c. The Producer Company can restrict the voting rights to only its active members  provided it is authorized by its Articles of Association.","Farmer Producer Organisations Frequently Asked Questions (Faqs),3.25 What Are The Voting Rights Of A Member?",,,,,86,input/md/english/FARMER PRODUCER ORGANISATIONS.pdf,para,,"Members of a Producer Company have voting rights based on their membership type - individual or producer institution. For a Producer Company with individual members, each member has one vote. If the company consists only of producer institutions, voting rights are based on participation in the previous year's business. The Producer Company can limit voting rights to active members if authorized by its Articles of Association."

77,85,"d. By completely transferring his/her shares e. By forfeiting his/her shares f. By a valid surrender g. By death h. By the company selling his shares in exercise of its right under its Articles of  Association  i. By order of a court or any other competent authority attaching and selling the shares,  in satisfaction of a decree or claim  j. By the official assignee disclaiming his shares, on his adjudication as an insolvent k. By rescission of contract of membership, on the grounds of misrepresentation or  mistake","Farmer Producer Organisations Frequently Asked Questions (Faqs),3.26 How A Member Is Ceased Of His/Her Membership?",,,,,87,input/md/english/FARMER PRODUCER ORGANISATIONS.pdf,para,,"Members can be ceased of their membership by completely transferring, forfeiting, or surrendering their shares, or by death. Additionally, membership can be ceased by the company selling shares in exercise of its rights, by court order attaching and selling shares, or by the official assignee disclaiming shares upon adjudication as an insolvent. Membership can also be ceased by rescission of the contract of membership on the grounds of misrepresentation or mistake."

78,67,"the Producer Company.  b. It should not act on the areas reserved for General Body. c. It should not exercise executive powers.    3.29 What are the matters, which the Board generally deals with?  a. Determination of the dividend payable; b. Determination of the quantum of withheld price and recommended patronage to be  approved at General Body Meeting;  c. Admission of new members; d. Pursue and formulate the organizational policy, objectives, establish long term and  annual objectives, and approve corporate strategies and financial plans;  e. Appointment of Chief Executive Officer (CEO) and other officers, as may be specified in  the AoA. Control CEO and other officers by exercising superintendence and direction;  f. To sanction any loan or advance to members, who are not directors or their relatives, in  the course of its business;  g. Ensure proper books are maintained; h. Acquire or dispose property of the company in the day-to-day affairs of the business; i.  Investment of the funds in the day to day business;  j. Ensure annual accounts are placed before the Annual General Meeting (AGM) with the  auditor's report. 3.30  Who appoints the Board of Directors?  a.","Farmer Producer Organisations Frequently Asked Questions (Faqs),3.27 How Many Board Of Directors Are Permitted In A Producer Company? A Producer Company Can Have A Minimum Of 5 Directors And Not More Than 15 Directors. 3.28 What Are The Powers And Functions Of The Board? A. The Board Is Responsible For Formulating, Supervising And Monitoring The Performance Of",,,,,188,input/md/english/FARMER PRODUCER ORGANISATIONS.pdf,para,,"The board of a producer company can have a minimum of 5 directors and a maximum of 15 directors. The board is responsible for formulating, supervising, and monitoring the performance of the producer company, but should not act on areas reserved for the General Body or exercise executive powers. Matters dealt with by the board include determining dividend payable, admission of new members, formulating organizational policy, appointing a CEO and other officers, sanctioning loans or advances to members, ensuring proper books are maintained, acquiring or disposing of property, and investing funds in the day-to-day business. The board of directors is appointed by the members of the producer company."

79,67,The names of the first Board of Directors are indicated in the MoA b. The AGM elects the directors in the first meeting and thereafter whenever requiredThe tenure of a director appointed by AGM is minimum one year and a maximum of 5 years.,"Farmer Producer Organisations Frequently Asked Questions (Faqs),3.27 How Many Board Of Directors Are Permitted In A Producer Company? A Producer Company Can Have A Minimum Of 5 Directors And Not More Than 15 Directors. 3.28 What Are The Powers And Functions Of The Board? A. The Board Is Responsible For Formulating,3.31 What Is The Period Of Tenure For The Directors?, Supervising And Monitoring The Performance Of",,,,,45,input/md/english/FARMER PRODUCER ORGANISATIONS.pdf,para,,"A Producer Company can have a minimum of 5 directors and not more than 15 directors. The Board is responsible for formulating, supervising, and monitoring the performance of the company. The names of the first Board of Directors are indicated in the MoA, and the AGM elects the directors in the first meeting and whenever required. The tenure of a director appointed by AGM is a minimum of one year and a maximum of 5 years."

80,89,a. Any person who is having expert knowledge in running the Producer Company can be  co-opted by the Board as an expert director.  b. Expert directors will not have right to vote in the election of Chairman.  c. Expert directors should not exceed one fifth of the total number of directors. d. Expert director can become a Chairman.,"Farmer Producer Organisations Frequently Asked Questions (Faqs),3.32 Who Is An Expert Director?",,,,,58,input/md/english/FARMER PRODUCER ORGANISATIONS.pdf,para,,"Expert directors in a Farmer Producer Organisation are individuals with specialized knowledge in running the Producer Company and can be co-opted by the Board. They do not have the right to vote in the election of the Chairman and should not exceed one fifth of the total number of directors. Despite this, an expert director can still become a Chairman."

81,90,"If a regular director is out of the State in which the meetings are held, for a period of 3 months or more, another person can be appointed as director in his place, who is called an alternate director.  The tenure of the alternate director must be not less than 3 months.  The moment the original director returns, the alternate Director ceases to be the Director.","Farmer Producer Organisations Frequently Asked Questions (Faqs),3.33 Who Is An Alternate Director?",,,,,66,input/md/english/FARMER PRODUCER ORGANISATIONS.pdf,para,,"An alternate director can be appointed if a regular director is out of the state for 3 months or more. The alternate director's tenure must be at least 3 months. Once the original director returns, the alternate director ceases to be the director."

82,91,"Generally the Directors are reimbursed the cash expenditure incurred by them for attending the board meetings like expenditure on travel, lodging and food.  However, if any Director, spends more time for the company, provisions may be made for providing fixed allowances like communication allowance, fixed daily allowance etc.","Farmer Producer Organisations Frequently Asked Questions (Faqs),3.34 How The Directors Are Remunerated?",,,,,48,input/md/english/FARMER PRODUCER ORGANISATIONS.pdf,para,,"The Directors of Farmer Producer Organisations are reimbursed for cash expenditure incurred for attending board meetings, including travel, lodging, and food. Additional provisions may be made for fixed allowances such as communication allowance and fixed daily allowance if a Director spends more time for the company."

83,92,"Only individuals can be directors of a company.  No educational qualification or minimum holding of shares is required.  Hence any individual can become a Director as per Section 465(1) of Companies Act, 2013.a. The shareholder directors of the company can be removed before the tenure by passing  an ordinary resolution at a general body meeting.  b. The Director ceases his post on completion of the tenure which ranges from 1 to 5 years.","Farmer Producer Organisations Frequently Asked Questions (Faqs),3.36 What Is The Procedure For Removing Directors?,3.35 What Should Be The Qualification Of A Director?",,,,,74,input/md/english/FARMER PRODUCER ORGANISATIONS.pdf,para,,"Directors of a company can be individuals without specific educational qualifications or share holdings. Shareholder directors can be removed before their tenure by passing an ordinary resolution at a general body meeting. The tenure of a director typically ranges from 1 to 5 years, after which they cease their post."

84,94,"a. Any Director can resign from his post by giving intimation to the company in a manner  indicated in the AoA.  b. If AoA do not indicate any procedure for resignation, then a Director can resign by giving  reasonable notice. The resignation is deemed as accepted the moment the notice is given.  c. In case of Chief Executive Officer or Managing Director or whole-time Director, mere  notice of resignation will not be deemed as resignation.  Their resignation will be governed by the terms and conditions of the appointment.  In this case acceptance of the resignation is required to get relieved of their duties.","Farmer Producer Organisations Frequently Asked Questions (Faqs),3.37 What Is The Procedure For Resignation Of Director/S?",,,,,103,input/md/english/FARMER PRODUCER ORGANISATIONS.pdf,para,,"Directors can resign by following the procedure in the Articles of Association or by giving reasonable notice if no procedure is specified. Resignation is considered accepted upon notice. However, for certain positions like CEO or Managing Director, resignation acceptance is necessary as per their appointment terms. The resignation process is governed by the terms and conditions of the appointment."

85,96,"a. A full time CEO is appointed by the Board of Directors as per AoA b. The CEO is to be other than a member c. The CEO is accountable to both the Board of Directors and membersa. A director or an officer who fails to provide information to a member or a person, for  whom he is required to provide information about the Producer Company, the Director is liable for imprisonment for a term extending to 6 months and with a fine equivalent to 5% of turnover of the company in the previous year  b. If there is a failure for convening an Annual General Meeting or other general meetings,  the Director shall be punishable with a fine extended up to Rs. 1 lakh.  In case the default continues, an additional fine extended up to Rs. 10,000/- per day.","Farmer Producer Organisations Frequently Asked Questions (Faqs),3.39 Who Appoints The Ceo And What Are His/Her Functions?",,,,,141,input/md/english/FARMER PRODUCER ORGANISATIONS.pdf,para,,"The CEO of a Farmer Producer Organisation is appointed by the Board of Directors and must be someone other than a member. The CEO is accountable to both the Board of Directors and the members. Failure to provide information about the Producer Company can result in imprisonment for up to 6 months and a fine equivalent to 5% of the company's turnover. Additionally, failure to convene meetings can lead to fines of up to Rs. 1 lakh, with an additional daily fine if the default continues."

86,77,"The functions of a CEO include the following:  a. Do administrative acts of routine nature including managing the day-to-day affairs of the  Company;  b. operate bank accounts or authorize any person, subject to the general or special approval  of the Board;   c. make arrangements for safe custody of cash and other assets of the Company; d. sign business related documents as may be 'authorized by the Board' for and on behalf of  the Producer Company;  e. maintain proper books of account, prepare annual accounts, place the audited accounts  before the Board and in the Annual General Meeting of the Members;  f. furnish the members with periodic information to appraise them of the operation and  functions of the Company;  g. make appointments to posts in accordance with the powers delegated to him by the  Board;  h. assist the Board in the formation of goals, objectives, strategies, plans and policies; i. advise the Board with respect to legal and regulatory matters concerning the proposed  and ongoing activities and take necessary action in respect thereof;  j. exercise the powers as may be necessary in the ordinary course of business; k.","Farmer Producer Organisations Frequently Asked Questions (Faqs),3.40 What Are The Functions Of A Ceo?",,,,,187,input/md/english/FARMER PRODUCER ORGANISATIONS.pdf,para,,"The CEO's functions include administrative tasks, managing day-to-day affairs, operating bank accounts, and ensuring safe custody of company assets. They are also responsible for signing business documents authorized by the Board, maintaining proper accounts, and providing members with regular updates. Additionally, the CEO makes appointments, assists in forming goals and strategies, advises on legal and regulatory matters, and exercises necessary powers in the ordinary course of business."

87,77,"discharge such other functions, and exercise such other powers, as may be delegated by  the Board;  l. to provide timely information to the Members and Board of Directors for scheduled  company meetings or emergency or short notice meetings.a. As indicated in AoA, the qualifications, experience and the terms and conditions  of service of the Chief Executive shall be such as may be determined by the Board.  b. The Chief Executive Officer (CEO) of a Producer Company shall be a full time  employee of the company.  c. The CEO shall be appointed by the Board of Directors of the company amongst  persons other than members.  d. The CEO shall be ex-officio director of the Board and such director shall not retire  by rotation.","Farmer Producer Organisations Frequently Asked Questions (Faqs),3.40 What Are The Functions Of A Ceo?,3.41 What Is The Minimum Qualification For Appointment Of A Ceo In A Producer Company?",,,,,123,input/md/english/FARMER PRODUCER ORGANISATIONS.pdf,para,,"The CEO of a Producer Company is responsible for discharging functions delegated by the Board and providing timely information to members and the Board. The qualifications, experience, and terms of service for the CEO are determined by the Board as per the Articles of Association. The CEO must be a full-time employee of the company and appointed by the Board from persons other than members. Additionally, the CEO serves as an ex-officio director of the Board and does not retire by rotation."

88,100,"a. Small Farmers' Agribusiness Consortium (SFAC): This organization provides  facilities to the agriculturists in the following manner:  i. It links the agriculturist with the banks which in turn provide the requisite  financial assistance.  ii. It provides training to the farmers on the various aspects of their activities  viz., use of various technologies, selection of the appropriate fertilizers, etc.  b. The various Non-Governmental Organizations which have promoted the  Producer Companies  are:","Farmer Producer Organisations Frequently Asked Questions (Faqs),3.42 Provide Details Of A Few Institutes Promoting The Establishment And Management Of The Producer Companies? The Establishment And The Management Of The Producer Companies Are Undertaken By Various Institutions As Indicated Below:",,,,,70,input/md/english/FARMER PRODUCER ORGANISATIONS.pdf,para,,"Various institutions promote the establishment and management of producer companies, including the Small Farmers' Agribusiness Consortium (SFAC), which provides facilities and links agriculturists with banks for financial assistance. SFAC also offers training to farmers on various aspects of their activities. Additionally, non-governmental organizations have also played a role in promoting producer companies."

column4: ,Farmer Producer Organisations Frequently Asked Questions (Faqs),3.42 Provide Details Of A Few Institutes Promoting The Establishment And Management Of The Producer Companies? The Establishment And The Management Of The Producer Companies Are Undertaken By Various Institutions As Indicated Below:",,,,,116,input/md/english/FARMER PRODUCER ORGANISATIONS.pdf,table,,"Various institutions promoting the establishment and management of producer companies include Masuta Producer Company Limited, which provides professional assistance for reeling and spinning tussar yarn. Indian Farmers Movement (Infarm) is involved in promoting vanilla production and marketing, adhering to international standards. Evangelical Social Action Forum (ESAF) supports small rural producers of handicrafts, herbal products, agri-food, dairy, and meat products, offering capacity building, production, value addition, quality assurance, and marketing. Panchakroshi Pashusamvardhan Producer Company Limited focuses on stall-fed goat rearing by small farmers. Additionally, Maharashtra Goat and Sheep Research Development Institute (MGSRD) and Nimbalkar Agricultural Research Institute (NARI) are also involved in promoting the establishment and management of producer companies."

column1: 90,102,"a. In addition to the above organizations, Action for Social Advancement (ASA) has  assisted in the establishment of sixteen Producer Companies in Madhya Pradesh and Bihar.  b. Of the number of the Producer Companies formed, there are Producer Companies  which have been successful viz., India Organic Farmers Producer Company Limited, Vanilla India Producer Company Limited, Rangsutra Craft Duniya Producer Company Limited, Masuta Producer Company Limited, ESAF Swasraya Producer Company Limited, etc.","Farmer Producer Organisations Frequently Asked Questions (Faqs),3.42 Provide Details Of A Few Institutes Promoting The Establishment And Management Of The Producer Companies? The Establishment And The Management Of The Producer Companies Are Undertaken By Various Institutions As Indicated Below:",,,,,71,input/md/english/FARMER PRODUCER ORGANISATIONS.pdf,para,,"Various institutions, including Action for Social Advancement (ASA), have assisted in establishing sixteen Producer Companies in Madhya Pradesh and Bihar. Successful Producer Companies include India Organic Farmers Producer Company Limited, Vanilla India Producer Company Limited, Rangsutra Craft Duniya Producer Company Limited, Masuta Producer Company Limited, and ESAF Swasraya Producer Company Limited."

91,82,"a. A Producer Company is a hybrid between a Private Limited Company and a  Cooperative Society, thus enjoying the benefits of professional management of a Private Limited Company as well as mutual benefits derived from a Cooperative Society.  b. Ownership and membership of a Producer Company is held only by ""primary  producers"" or ""Producer Institution/s"" and member's equity cannot be traded. Hence, nobody can take over the company or deprive the primary producers of their organisation.  c. The clauses of Private Limited Company shall be applicable to the producer companies  except the clauses specified in Producer Company Act from 581-A to 581-ZL which make it different from a normal private or limited company (refer the Producer Company Act for details). This enables a professional framework for a Producer Company.  d. The liability of the members is limited to the unpaid amount of the shares held by  them.  Hence, the private assets of the members are safe from company losses.  e. The minimum paid-up Capital being Rs. 1 Lakh and minimum authorized capital being  Rs.5 lakh for a PC, it easy to mobilise the small amount.   f.","Farmer Producer Organisations Frequently Asked Questions (Faqs),3.43 What Are The Advantages Of A Producer Company?",,,,,186,input/md/english/FARMER PRODUCER ORGANISATIONS.pdf,para,,"A Producer Company is a hybrid between a Private Limited Company and a Cooperative Society, enjoying professional management and mutual benefits. Ownership and membership are held only by ""primary producers"" or ""Producer Institution/s"" and member's equity cannot be traded, protecting the primary producers. The clauses of a Private Limited Company apply to producer companies, except for specific clauses in the Producer Company Act, creating a professional framework. Members' liability is limited to the unpaid amount of shares held by them, safeguarding their private assets. With a minimum paid-up capital of Rs. 1 Lakh and minimum authorized capital of Rs. 5 lakh, it is easy to mobilize small amounts for a Producer Company."

92,82,"Minimum number of producers required to form a PC is 10 while there is no limit for  maximum number of members and the membership can be increased as per feasibility and need. This helps even 10 individuals start a Producer Company which is easy.  g. There cannot be any government or private equity stake in the Producer Companies,  which implies that PC cannot become a public or deemed public limited company. Hence, any Government or other corporate threat is non-existent in professional functioning of the company.  h. The area of operation for a PC is the entire country giving flexibility to expand and do  business in a free and professional manner.","Farmer Producer Organisations Frequently Asked Questions (Faqs),3.43 What Are The Advantages Of A Producer Company?",,,,,111,input/md/english/FARMER PRODUCER ORGANISATIONS.pdf,para,,"Producer Companies (PCs) require a minimum of 10 producers to form, with no limit on maximum members. This allows even 10 individuals to easily start a Producer Company. Government or private equity stake is not allowed in PCs, ensuring professional functioning without external influence. PCs have the flexibility to operate nationwide, enabling expansion and professional business conduct."

93,105,"a. A Producer Company is to be registered as per the Part IXA of Indian Companies Act  1956, Reference Section 465(1) of the Companies Act 2013. It is a must to register the company and non-registered entities are not given the benefit of the Act.  b. Registration of a Producer Company is a bit difficult, generally requiring the services  of a consultant.  c. The registration of a Producer Company is a sometimes time consuming process. d. The members cannot transfer their shares freely. e. Getting a professional CEO at an affordable cost is little difficult.  f. The Producer Company should follow the statutory provisions of Indian Companies  Act and should comply with the mandatory prescriptions of the Act without fail which is little difficult for the illiterate members to understand.","Farmer Producer Organisations Frequently Asked Questions (Faqs),3.44 What Are The Limitations Of A Producer Company?",,,,,130,input/md/english/FARMER PRODUCER ORGANISATIONS.pdf,para,,"The limitations of a Producer Company include the requirement for registration under the Indian Companies Act, which can be challenging and time-consuming. Additionally, members cannot freely transfer their shares, and obtaining a professional CEO at an affordable cost may be difficult. The company must also comply with statutory provisions and mandatory prescriptions of the Act, which can be challenging for illiterate members to understand."

94,106,"Note:  Please refer to the Companies Act 1956 and Companies Act 2013 and also the notifications, thereof.A society may be defined as a company or association of persons (generally unincorporated) united together by mutual consent to deliberate, determine and act jointly for some common purpose.","Farmer Producer Organisations Frequently Asked Questions (Faqs),3.45 Provide A Flowchart For Formation Of A Producer Company? Submission Module Obtain Certificate Of Commencement,Chapter 4 Producer Organisation Registered As Non-Profit Society 4.1 What Is A Society?",,,,,46,input/md/english/FARMER PRODUCER ORGANISATIONS.pdf,para,,"The formation of a producer company involves obtaining a Certificate of Commencement and following the guidelines provided in the Companies Act 1956 and Companies Act 2013. A society is a company or association of persons united by mutual consent to deliberate, determine, and act jointly for a common purpose. This definition is generally unincorporated and is outlined in Chapter 4 of the Producer Organisation Registered as Non-Profit Society. It is important to refer to the relevant notifications and legal provisions for a clear understanding of the process."

95,108,"As per Societies Registration Act, 1860, a society can be formed by minimum seven persons eligible to enter into contract. Individuals (excluding minors but including foreigners), partnership firms, companies and registered societies are eligible to form a society.The society can be registered for any of the following purposes:   a. Grant of charitable assistance b. Creation of military orphan fund c. Promotion of literature, science and fine arts, etc. d. Some states like Delhi and Gujarat also allow welfare and other purposes as eligible  purpose.","Farmer Producer Organisations Frequently Asked Questions (Faqs),4.2 Who Can Form A Society?,4.3 For What Purposes A Society Can Be Registered?",,,,,85,input/md/english/FARMER PRODUCER ORGANISATIONS.pdf,para,,"A society can be formed by a minimum of seven eligible persons, including individuals, partnership firms, companies, and registered societies. The purposes for which a society can be registered include granting charitable assistance, creating military orphan funds, promoting literature, science, and fine arts, and other welfare purposes as allowed by certain states. This is in accordance with the Societies Registration Act, 1860."

96,111,"A society for its inception requires following documents:   a. Memorandum of Association b. Rules and RegulationsThe certificate issued by the Registrar of Societies or any other competent authority is valid for a particular period and then it is to be renewed. For example, registration of society is valid for a period of 5 years in UP.","Farmer Producer Organisations Frequently Asked Questions (Faqs),4.5 What Are The Documents Required For Inception Of The Society",,,,,57,input/md/english/FARMER PRODUCER ORGANISATIONS.pdf,para,,"The documents required for the inception of a society include the Memorandum of Association and Rules and Regulations. The certificate issued by the Registrar of Societies or a competent authority is valid for a specific period and needs to be renewed, such as every 5 years in UP."

97,90,"Memorandum of Association is the charter of the society. It describes the objects of society's existence and its operations.  4.7 What does Memorandum of association of a society contain?     The memorandum of association shall contain the following things:  a. the name of the society; b. the object of the society; c. the names, addresses, and occupations of the governors, council, directors,  committee, or other governing body to whom, by the rules of the society, the management of its affairs is entrusted.    A copy of the rules and regulations of the society, certified to be a correct copy by not less than three of the members of the governing body, shall be filed with the memorandum of association. 4.8 What is the purpose of rules and regulation of the society? The rules and regulations are framed to guide the members of the governing body and to regulate the functions of the society and its internal management. 4.9 What does the rules and regulations of a society contain? The rules and regulations generally contain-  a. The conditions of admission of members. b. The liability of members for fines, forfeitures under certain circumstances; c.","Farmer Producer Organisations Frequently Asked Questions (Faqs),4.6 What Is A Memorandum Of Association?",,,,,191,input/md/english/FARMER PRODUCER ORGANISATIONS.pdf,para,,"The Memorandum of Association is the charter of the society, outlining its purpose and operations. It includes the society's name, objectives, and the details of the governing body. Additionally, a certified copy of the society's rules and regulations must be filed with the memorandum of association. The rules and regulations are designed to guide the governing body and regulate the society's internal management. They typically cover conditions of member admission and member liabilities for fines and forfeitures."

98,90," The termination of membership by resignation or expulsion or upon death;  d. The appointment and removal of trustees and their powers; e. 103,120,"In simple words, it is a transfer of property by the owner to another for the benefit of a third person along with or without himself or a declaration by the owner, to hold the property not for himself but for another or another and himself.","Farmer Producer Organisations Frequently Asked Questions (Faqs),5.2 What Is A Trust?",,,,,46,input/md/english/FARMER PRODUCER ORGANISATIONS.pdf,para,,"A trust is a transfer of property by the owner to another for the benefit of a third person, with or without the owner's involvement. 104,121,"A person who creates a Trust is called a settlor, the person to whom the property is transferred on trust is called a trustee and the person for whose benefit the property is transferred is called the beneficiary.There are two types of Trusts namely public trust and private trust. A public charitable Trust is one, which benefits the public at large, or some considerable portion of it. Private Trusts' income is available to specified beneficiaries and not to the public at large."

109,128,"Section 11(4A) of the Income Tax Act, 1961 has been amended with effect from 1-4-1992. Accordingly, if the income from business is incidental to the attainment of the objects of the non-profit organisation and separate books of account are maintained by such an organisation in respect of such business, the profit is not considered for taxation. In other words, the profit is fully exempt from tax. Income from a business undertaking which is itself held under Trust for charitable purpose [under section 11(1) (a)] is also exempt. Further, an","Farmer Producer Organisations Frequently Asked Questions (Faqs),5.12 Can Ngos Take Up Business Activities?",,,,,89,input/md/english/FARMER PRODUCER ORGANISATIONS.pdf,para,,"NGOs can engage in business activities as long as the income generated is incidental to the organization's non-profit objectives. The Income Tax Act of 1961 allows for full tax exemption on profits if the business income is related to the non-profit organization's goals and separate accounting books are maintained for the business activities. Additionally, income from a business undertaking held under Trust for charitable purposes is also exempt from taxation. This provision enables NGOs to undertake business activities while enjoying tax benefits, provided that the income generated aligns with their non-profit objectives and is accounted for separately."

113,133,"Section 8 Companies are those companies which are formed for the sole purpose of promoting commerce, art, science, religion, charity or any other useful object.   a. 114,134,"Section 8 Company is preferred as compared to Trust, society because of following reasons:  a. Section 8 Company has uniform law across the country. b. Section 8 Companies are also preferred, as compared to others, in foreign funding  because of stringent disclosure norms and regulatory provisions under Companies Act, 1956 and Foreign Contribution Regulation Act.    c. The Central and State Governments recognised Section 8 Company in various Schemes  implemented by them.   d. A wide range of activities can be taken up. e. Exempted from using the word Private Limited or Limited f. Members/Owners easily transfer ownership in shares and interest by the manner  provided by the Article of Association.   g. The continuation of an incorporated Section 8 Company is unaffected by the death of  any of its owner(s) or the transfer of its shares to a new entity/person","Farmer Producer Organisations Frequently Asked Questions (Faqs),6.2 What Advantages Do The Producers Organisations Get On Registering Themselves As Section 8 Companies?",,,,,138,input/md/english/FARMER PRODUCER ORGANISATIONS.pdf,para,,"Registering as a Section 8 Company offers several advantages to producer organisations. Section 8 Companies can engage in a wide range of activities and are exempted from using specific terms in their name. Additionally, members can easily transfer ownership in shares and interest, and the company's continuation is unaffected by changes in ownership."

115,135,"The followings are the disadvantages of Section 8 Company:-  a. Profits cannot be distributed as dividends to members and it will be applied for  promoting its objects only.   b. Alteration in the objects clause of the Company requires prior approval of Central  Government.   c. In comparison to Society and Trust, registration of Section 8 Company and complying  with other terms & conditions are costly.  Also, if there is any breach of law, a Section 8 Company has to bear penalties and fines.    d. Section 8 Companies also fall under the definition of Company under Income tax.  Therefore, same rate of tax is applicable to Section 8 Companies which is applicable to the normal profit making company.   e. Generally, complete closure or winding of Section 8 Companies takes around 1-2 years  and involves compliance of various formalities. Moreover, in certain cases, it requires the approval from the High Court.","Farmer Producer Organisations Frequently Asked Questions (Faqs),6.3 What Are The Disadvantages Of A Section 8 Company?",,,,,148,input/md/english/FARMER PRODUCER ORGANISATIONS.pdf,para,,"A Section 8 Company has several disadvantages, including the inability to distribute profits as dividends to members and the requirement to use profits for promoting its objects only. Additionally, Section 8 Companies face higher registration and compliance costs, as well as potential penalties and fines for breaches of the law. These companies also fall under the same tax rate as normal profit-making companies. Finally, the closure or winding up of Section 8 Companies can be a lengthy process, taking around 1-2 years and involving various formalities and potential approval from the High Court."

123,121,"7.1 What is the concept of value chain development?  Value chain comprises all the activities at different yet interlinked stages that add value to a particular product through the different phases of production, including procurement of raw materials and other inputs. Usually, there are many actors along the value chain for producing, transforming/processing and bringing goods and services to end-consumers through a series of sequential activities. When the produce originates from agriculture, we call it an agricultural value chain. Let us take the case of milk. For producing milk, the farmer requires milch cattle, feed and fodder and shed for the cattle. After milking (once/twice a day), the milk is taken to the collection centre where the volume, fat and SNF contents are measured. From the collection centre, milk is transported to the Bulk Milk Chilling Unit, where the milk is filtered and chilled to keep it fresh. From there, it goes to Milk Processing Plant, where bacteria is de-activated through pasteurization, and different types of milk and milk products are made. Liquid milk (whole milk, toned milk, vitamin-A fortified milk) is made into packets and sent to wholesalers.","Farmer Producer Organisations Frequently Asked Questions (Faqs),Chapter 7 Business Planning",,,,,189,input/md/english/FARMER PRODUCER ORGANISATIONS.pdf,para,,"Value chain development involves all the interconnected activities that add value to a product through various production stages, including sourcing raw materials and other inputs. In an agricultural context, this is known as agricultural value chain, such as in the case of milk production. The process involves activities like measuring volume, fat, and SNF contents at the collection center, transporting milk to the Bulk Milk Chilling Unit, and then to the Milk Processing Plant for pasteurization and production of various milk products. Finally, the products are packaged and sent to wholesalers for distribution."

124,121,"The retailers get milk packets from the wholesalers and sell to the consumers through milk booth and/or through door delivery. Processed milk products like butter, curd, cheese, ghee etc., also reach the end-consumers from the processing facility thorough the same channel. The whole chain from purchasing of milch cattle to delivery of milk packets to consumers is the value chain for milk. Though value is added at each stage, major addition takes place through Milk Chilling, Pasteurisation and Processing. All the persons/agencies undertaking one or more activities in this chain are called the actors in the value chain.","Farmer Producer Organisations Frequently Asked Questions (Faqs),Chapter 7 Business Planning",,,,,98,input/md/english/FARMER PRODUCER ORGANISATIONS.pdf,para,,"The value chain for milk involves various actors from purchasing milch cattle to delivering milk packets to consumers. Retailers obtain milk packets from wholesalers and distribute them through milk booths or door delivery. Processed milk products like butter, curd, cheese, and ghee also follow the same distribution channel to reach consumers. While value is added at each stage of the chain, significant addition occurs during milk chilling, pasteurization, and processing. The individuals or entities involved in any part of this chain are referred to as actors in the value chain."

125,146,"7.2 What is value chain intervention?  The PO may choose to undertake any one or more than one activity of the value chain. In the example above, the PO may manufacture/procure concentrate feed and supply it to the farmers. It can purchase milch cattle in bulk from outside the state for the members. It can establish Bulk Milk Chilling Unit or Milk Processing Plant. It can purchase refrigerated vans for transport of milk and milk products. 137,127,"The first step is to identify and map the processes/factors that would have the biggest  impact on earnings, if disrupted. For example, bad monsoon will severely affect crop production in rain-fed areas thus reducing earning of the PO considerably.  b. The second step is to identify critical infrastructure —including processes,  relationships, people, regulations, plant, and equipment—that supports the PO's ability to generate earnings. For example, if there is break-down in the Bulk Milk Chilling Unit, the whole stock of milk will be spoilt and go waste, besides adversely affecting the supply chain.   c. The third step is to identify the main vulnerabilities. Vulnerability is inability to cope  with the adverse effects of an event or risk. For example, storage, processing and trading of commodities can come under new regulation, imposing conditions, which the PO may find difficult to comply with, at short notice.   d. The fourth step is to identify the weakest links, the elements on which all the others  depend. For example, if there is a single buyer for all produces, this is the weakest link.   e. The last step is to develop planned response to mitigate the risks.","Farmer Producer Organisations Frequently Asked Questions (Faqs),7.19 How Does One Generate Business Ideas? Identification Of Specific Business Opportunity Is Largely A Reactive Process. Some Of The Ways To Hit Upon A Business Idea Are Given Below:",,,,,190,input/md/english/FARMER PRODUCER ORGANISATIONS.pdf,para,,"Identification of specific business opportunities for Farmer Producer Organisations involves mapping processes and factors with the biggest impact on earnings, identifying critical infrastructure, and pinpointing vulnerabilities and weakest links. For example, a bad monsoon could severely affect crop production, while a breakdown in infrastructure like the Bulk Milk Chilling Unit could lead to spoilage of milk and disruption of the supply chain. Additionally, new regulations could pose challenges for storage, processing, and trading of commodities. Ultimately, developing a planned response to mitigate these risks is crucial for generating business ideas."

139,128,"The Food Safety and Standards Authority of India (FSSAI) has been established under Food Safety and Standards Act, 2006 which consolidates various acts & orders that have hitherto handled food related issues in various Ministries and Departments. It has been mandated to perform the following functions:  a. Framing of Regulations to lay down the Standards and guidelines in relation to articles  of food and specifying appropriate system of enforcing various standards thus notified.  b. Laying down mechanisms and guidelines for accreditation of certification bodies  engaged in certification of food safety management system for food businesses.  c. Laying down procedure and guidelines for accreditation of laboratories and  notification of the accredited laboratories.  d. To provide scientific advice and technical support to Central Government and State  Governments in the matters of framing the policy and rules in areas which have a direct or indirect bearing of food safety and nutrition.  e.","Farmer Producer Organisations Frequently Asked Questions (Faqs),7.24 What Are The Functions Of The Food Safety And Standards Authority Of India (Fssai)?",,,,,184,input/md/english/FARMER PRODUCER ORGANISATIONS.pdf,para,,"The Food Safety and Standards Authority of India (FSSAI) was established under the Food Safety and Standards Act, 2006 to lay down science-based standards for food and regulate its manufacture, storage, distribution, sale, and import. FSSAI aims to enforce standards for food articles and food safety management systems, as well as provide guidance for accreditation and scientific support to government bodies."
